To answer this question, we need to consider two issues: planning and metaphoricity.

In fact, reviewing a number of studies on writing processes, Hayes and Nash (1996) have shown that planning is not more valuable than other writing processes such as text generation or revising and that the proportion of time devoted to planning does not make a better piece of writing.

On the other hand, if we are talking about metaphoricity in her verbal reports, i.e., the core issue, two sub-questions arise: is this metaphoricity a thinking mechanism, or is it a response mechanism stimulated by the task?
In the first case, as current metaphor scholarship has proved, metaphoric thinking would be part of the thinking process, regardless of the presence of planning.
